h_title_comment: What do you expect from a 8 dollar room hotel
h_comment: It has a bed, a bathroom, a fan (no airco), warm water, a mini TV and some electricity sockets that work if you plug in your device in a specific angle. Bring earplugs, really: the fan alone can keep godzilla awake. This is the real Vietnam treatment. Not the friendliest service.

The rooms are dated, simple, a bit dusty, but overall fine for a few nights. The staff are hit and miss depending on who you get. English levels vary. Breakfast was bread and eggs of some form, as usual in Vietnam. Very centrally located to get round everywhere.
h

We booked this place as it was at a convenient stop on our way motorbiking to HCMC. It was hard to find (and incorrectly located on google maps/booking.com which said it was right next to the springs, it is not).   On arriving, it was clear no one in the hotel spoke English. They seemed impatient to usher us to our room a little walk away.   The room was very depressing and smelt damp and unclean. The toilets were pretty filthy and towels very dirty too. We had a hunt for the AC remote as it was sweltering in the room but had to request one from reception, that didn't seem to work. The biggest issue for us were the mosquitoes and because the room was unprotected (nets and uncovered windows) our room was swarming with them. We stayed for around 10 minutes and after being bitten  20-30 times each decided to leave. The hotel staff were not pleased, and it took a good few minutes to rescue our passports before we could go.  Don't waste your money unless you want to be mosquito food.

h_title_comment: Our high hopes of this place were dashed from the first moment we arrived.
h_comment: We booked Long Chau because it was considerably cheaper than the other hostels in Chau Doc and, we foolishly decided, any money we would spend on motos into town, would be saved in the room price. Also, the hotel website promised bicycles to rent and had a restaurant so we felt like we wouldn't need to go to Chau Doc that much anyway.  On our arrival, it became apparent that no one at the hotel spoke English. The moto driver who dropped us off spoke excellent English, waited around while we got checked it and implored the reception staff to help carry my girlfriend's heavy backpack to the room. We were shown to our room which was a basic double with a fan and was quite large.  However, the fan was mounted precariously to the wall opposite the bed and it was on a sweep cycle  which we couldn't switch off. Indeed, in trying to stop the fan's pointless movement, I nearly sliced my finger off. That would have been my fault for being stupid but what is the point in a fan if it just wafts air in every direction apart from the bed.  Furthermore, there was no WiFi in the room. I seem to remember it being advertised on the website as having WiFi but I thought it might have been in public places. We went to the restaurant to try and use it there but were informed they did not have WiFi.  We decided to take advantage of the bicycles the hotel had to offer and ride into town for dinner. We asked if we could rent a bike and got a blank response. After several minutes of acting out bike we were told they had no bikes and that was that. As such, we decided to try and walk the 6km into town, in scorching heat and eventually settled on a cyclo about 1km from the hotel.  The next morning, we breakfasted at the hotel. The menu was basic and we asked for pancakes. 'No pancakes' came the reply. 'Cereal?' We asked, 'no cereal.' All they could offer was bread, jam and butter for $1. Not good. We asked if they could arrange a moto to town and they said yes so imagine our surprise when a taxi arrived. We couldn't argue so we bit the bullet and paid the $3 to town.  After a long day of traipsing around Chau Doc trying to find something to do to kill time, we decided to get an early night as we were getting an early morning boat to Phnom Penh the next day. Unfortunately, when we tried to order dinner at the hotel restaurant, we quickly discovered the only thing they could offer us from the menu (which included steak, fish, pork, seafood, chicken etc) was noodles. Fantastic.  Another expensive taxi to town and back, by now we'd spent well over the money we'd saved, was followed by yet another night of sleeping in a noisy sauna. To top this off, when we arrived back at the hotel at 2045 and the 'Manson Family' seemed reluctant to let us back in.  Our moto driver asked us how we'd found our stay and laughed knowingly when I said awful.

h_title_comment: Nice enough, though a little unloved.
h_comment: It might have been that we were visiting out of season, but the hotel and it's grounds seemed a touch neglected when we visited. The gardens were overgrown, the outdoor bar was full of strewn furniture and the dining hall was deserted. However, as we were leaving, we saw gardeners start to tackle the weeds growing up over the entrance, so it is possible that the neglect that we saw was just due to the time of year.The hotel is very difficult to find, it's 1km down a gravel road in the middle of nowhere, but is very clean and has friendly staff. The rural location is great fun though, especially if you are travelling with a motorbike, as we were. The neighbouring countryside has loads to explore, and there are plenty of local cafes and restaurants nearby. Overall, recommended,  try to get to the hotel at peak season if the appearance of the grounds bothers you.

A boy with moto meet me at the hotel when I arived with bus in the city I was a stupid usually I use trip advisor for my hotel. The hotel is no clean, no wifi you have to connect to the near hotels and the morning I hade to pay ten dollar and not 200000 dong as written on the wall, I have been in Vietnam one month it's the first time I think a hotel give me less than I pay

h_title_comment: Never seen a so bad and dirty Hotel
h_comment: We had a one month stay in Vietnam. The Tai Ngan Hotel was the worst hotel we had during our stay. We strongly recommend you not to choose this hotel. It is very dirty, there are little rats sh... on the bed !!! The balconey is full of moskitos. Further, the staff is impolite and not fair.

My friend and me actually wanted to stay in Thuan Loi Hotel, the one floating in the river. However, after we realised that it is full, we accepted a free motorbike ride from the owner of that floating inn to this alternative hotel.   We arenâ€™t willing to pay the same price for it though, because itâ€™s a different hotel without the river views after all. Eventually, we were quoted a lower price and the boss, who already seemed unhappy with this haggling, started selling a boat border crossing to Cambodia to us. We had planned on doing a land crossing so we adamantly refused their offers again. Then he claimed that no land crossing can be arranged from Chau Doc, which I donâ€™t believe for a second. By this point, even the hotel receptionist who spoke English seemed black faced as  well.   When we finally reached our room after navigating a staircase in darkness, we realised that though our room was big, it was sort of in disrepair. Amazingly, the receptionistâ€™s attitude changed 180 degrees during the rest of our stay in the hotel. She actually smiled at us on our way down to dinner! Leading us to seriously consider the possibility of her renegading on the price we agreed on when we had to check out the next day.   The location of the hotel was good, with lots of street food around to savour and just a short walk to the riverside. Asking around, we managed to book a land crossing from the receptionist at the nearby Hotel Hai Chau. Although we checked out of our hotel without incident the next morning, I believe that there are better places to stay out there for the same price. The stress and aggravation that we had to endure when we havenâ€™t even checked in is uncalled for, though the magical change in the receptionistâ€™s attitude during the rest of our stay earned that 2nd star from me.

Es gibt andere Hotels wo man mit Respekt behandelt wird aber hier nicht und im Gegenteil man muss sogar noch aufpassen nicht betrogen zu werden.Diese Zeilen schreibe ich aus Kambodscha wo ich problemlos mit dem Motorrad einreisen konnte.

Nous avons atteri dans cet hotel un peu par hasard car il est bien situÃ©. L'accueil est moyen (ils ont demandÃ© Ã  garder nos passeports le temps de notre sÃ©jour, ce que nous avons refusÃ©). La chambre est convenable, nous avions un balcon avec une vue sur la grande place. La salle de bains Ã©tait sale et vieille, les draps Ã©taient trouÃ©s, et nous n'avons pas pu dormir de la nuit Ã  cause du bruit Ã  l'extÃ©rieur comme Ã  l'intÃ©rieur.  Cet hotel est bon marchÃ© (environ 14 $US)

A notre arrivÃ©e, nous sommes dirigÃ©s vers la mauvaise chambre et devons la quitter alors que nous avions dÃ©jÃ  rangÃ© nos affaires. Salle de bain non nettoyÃ©e.  Draps de lit sales. Serviettes sales. Signal wifi faible Ã  certains Ã©tages. Aucun mot d'anglais de la part de la rÃ©ceptionniste. PrÃ©sence de moustiques et lÃ©zards dans les chambres. Aucune insonorisation. Une chambre 4 places est en fait dotÃ© d'un vrai lit double et d'un grand lit simple (3 places en tout donc).  On note une bonne clim, un bon wifi si on capte le signal, des matelas corrects et une tv en vietnamien. SituÃ© Ã  1.5 km du centre, 30 000 dongs en taxi.  A Ã©viter !

h_title_comment: has obviously improved in the last two years.
h_comment: Ended up here after an awful night at the hotel our moto driver 'recommend' (we knew that would be a mistake!) and, without wifi, took to checking a few out. We paid 290,000 dong for a really nice twin room. It was nice and clean, aircon, fridge, tv, bathroom were all great. Added bonus: small balcony overlooking the main square, good for people watching and getting washing dry overnight. The wonderfully friendly couple who run the shop/bookshop helped us book the bus for our next stop, and i later read online others recommending a local tour from him. All in all, a happy accident stay for us, and would easily recommend hotel sao song to others. My guess is that management and standards have changed since last reviews. Ps - yes, the early morning bells were annoying for a few  minutes, but we went straight back to sleep for a couple more blissful hours sleep. No other sounds woke us up

h_title_comment: Not my cup of tea but cheap as chips
h_comment: Location is nice upon first impression as it overlooks the town square, close to everything. However at 4am loud Public Announcements start followed by music at 5am, not for the weary traveller. Beds are very hard, linen very poor but clean. Airconditioning worked well. Bathroom basic and worn. Staff friendly but very limited english, hard to communicate. For those on a budget, excellent value! It's ok, but not for me.

We stayed at the Song Sao Hotel in Chau Doc and were very dissapointed, despite it being central and only $15 per night.   The plus's was it's central location and that it has a lift. The negatives were that they suggested the price included breakfast, but when we wnet to pay pointed out the fine print which showed it was U$4 more. Then they just smiled at you. The breakfast was crap and certainly not worth the money. Our room was also dirty and infested with ants whcih got into our bags. Overall the place needs a makeover and wasn't good value and the staff were dishonest.  You can do better. On a postive note we would definately agree with another reviewer that the old couple running the breakfast place/bookshop/ticket ofice next door were lovely and we booked our boat trip  through then to Phnom penh.

h_title_comment: Do not advice you to go here!
h_comment: I arrived late afternoon after a long day of traveling. I had to check in, but soon I found out nobody speaks English.. It is also far away from Chau Doc, I should have checked better when i booked through Agoda... The room is super small and not clean. When I checked the bathroom the floor was wet and the toilet seat up.. The pillow smelt like someone just slept there and there where hairs on the floar. The window did not close properly and it is a very noisy area with lots of buses and cars.. so I couldn't really sleep.. Also the air conditioning made a strange sound.. When I wanted to order some dinner, it was just impossible, I am vegetarian and tried my best with google translate when they send a guy to my room to ask what I wanted.. first there was food then there was only  breakfast... later a woman comes with  a phone so I could talk to someone who speaks English, suddenly I could order food, but it was after nine, and I already ate some fruit and chips I had left.. This hotel is just not made for foreigners in my opinion.. I paid $23 for this... NO GOOD!!! Ow and the wifi is also very poor...

h_comment: DecepÃ§Ã£o total! JÃ¡ no check-in nÃ£o encontramos ninguÃ©m. Depois chegou uma senhora no seu pior humor que telefonou para alguÃ©m que falava um pouco de ingles e entÃ£o nos encaminhou para o quarto. Haviamos reservado o que julgamos ser o melhor porÃ©m nos deram um sem janela. Diante dos nossos protestos o trocamos por um apartamento de frente com varanda compartilhada. Bem... uma cama tinha lenÃ§ol e fronha limpos, mas outra estava imunda, somente com uma forraÃ§Ã£o sobre a cama. NÃ£o dava coragem de usar. A descarga do sanitÃ¡rio nÃ£o funcionava. Concluo que o preÃ§o, ainda que barato, foi alto pelo que obtivemos. Principalmente porque na esquina hÃ¡

h_title_comment: You get what you pay for ;-)
h_comment: This hotel is probably one of the budget options in Chau Doc so don't expect too much. Although it's a bit run down it's a good place to stay for one or two nights. The cheapest room didn't have a window so I decided to pay little extra and got a nice room with a balcony.  Have seen places which are more clean but it was still ok.  Staff was really friendly until they found out that I booked my boat ticket at another place. After that they got really grumpy. So better don't tell them if you book your ticket anywhere else ;-)

h_title_comment: Decent budget choice, but be wary
h_comment: Arrived here by walking from the dock, after taking the speedboat from Phnom Penh. The room is not exactly sparkling clean, and quite hot due to a fairly poorly located fan. Polyester bed sheets are mind-bogglingly bad: who came up with that idea?!  However, for $10 a night we got two double beds, TV, fridge, hot water and a shared balcony. Wifi is reasonable and the owner friendly and with a good grasp of English. We did peek inside some other rooms and they looked significantly worse - I'd definitely pay extra for one at the front.  We wanted to move on to Can Tho, and the hotel offered us a bus ticket with transfers for 8$. Now, we know the bus fair is closer to 5$ so decided to go to the bus station and take care of it ourselves. The hotel owner offered us a moto for $1.50,

I ended up at the Ky An at 8pm on a Saturday night when I was unable to find any other available room anywhere in the town. I was beginning to panic, thinking that I would be spending the night out on the street, a thought which as I, a female, solo traveling, mobility handicapped, senior did not relish.  I took the first room available and it was the Ky An's last room, having tried at least a dozen other places first.  The Ky An is just around the corner from the bus station. I was woefully overcharged, $30 for a room which was not worth any more than $10 maximum.  The room was large, had 3 beds in it, but no sheets on the bed. There was no hot water. The rate did not include breakfast, and the place was very loud. It seemed as if every noise amplifying building material and  technique has been used in its construction. The lobby was used as a garage for their cars.  Avoid the Ky An if at all possible.

We booked this hotel through Booking.com when it was called Satisfy hotel,  for two nights as part of a 14 night holiday in Vietnam and Cambodia.   Before moving to Chau Doc we checked the web site and found that Booking.com were no longer taking bookings so rang them to check why.  They said they would contact the hotel and did not but in the meantime we realised that this hotel was one and the same and was advertised on Booking.com.   I rang back, told them what I had found out and they again said they would get back to me and this time they said it was under new ownership who would honour previous bookings.  However on arrival the manager? did not speak any English, could not seem to find our booking but showed us to a room with a balcony and view of a tin roof.  I managed to  mime that we had ordered a view of the pool and this time were taken to a room with a view but no balcony.  More miming and we finally got the room we had ordered.  Later realised we were the only people staying there.    Room ok although it could do with a new lick of paint. No sign of any breakfast or the advertised bicycles.  The restaurant was never open, the room was not cleaned or towels changed even though there seemed to be lots of staff with nothing to do.  I had to take an empty toilet roll to communicate we needed more. A cafe open at the front of the restaurant was moderately busy but we did not use it.

h_title_comment: An out of the way gem
h_comment: This hotel is reviewed in guide books under the name Delta Adventure Inn, but trying to locate it on the ground under this name is next to impossible.  Locally it goes by the name of Long Chau Resort.  It is out of Chau Doc, almost at the Sam Mountain settlement, and is set far enough back off the road to be away from traffic noise. The large restaurant is open on all sides, behind this is a lake with a pretty island, around which are approx 20 single story "cottages". The rooms are basic, but perfectly adequate, the beds are  comfortable, and the water is hot.  Breakfast is included in the room price, which ranges from 130,000 Dong to 240,000Dong. My room was in the middle at 180,000 Dong (16,000 dong to 1 US$)  I looked out onto rice paddys from the side window and onto the

We booked this relatively inexpensive clean and  modern hotel for family travelling with us. It is about 3 years old. There is a courtyard area at the front with steps up to reception area. The bedrooms are upstairs via lift or stairs being nicely furnished with wooden beds and ensuite bathrooms.It is family run and friendly - the elder son speaks some English. No breakfast provided but pho can be bought outside. It is a good location for temples (200 metres) and local shops for drinks and fruit. For a stopover fine.

ho soggiornato solo una notte dovendomi fermare ho guardato in internet e ho preso la guesthouse piÃ¹ econimica, un letto pulito , un bagno, internet, tutto quello che mi serviva. personale disponibile e di aiuto

I was just there for one night on my way to Cambodia (by the Hang Chau boat the next morning) from HCM City, and so there was a pickup shuttle (thanks to the hotel manager who told me that in advance :) ) and it was just about a ten minute ride to the hotel (I was the first to be dropped off).  The lady at the desk called the Hang Chau boat office right away to confirm my pickup for the next morning, so that was very, very nice of them! :)  And, the staff also made sure that I was up the next morning by coming to knock on my door and all that, so yes very impressed with their hospitality service :).  Was picked up by a foot-pedalled richshaw in the morning and got to the boat dock in just like 20 minutes.  There's a noodle/soup restaurant like right beside the hotel turning left  towards the main road after getting out of the hotel (the restaurant is right on the corner but you have to enter it from the main road), and you get to the Bassac River (there may be another name for it too) by turning left again onto the main road and walking about ten minutes, and there are quite a few places to eat along that main road as well like places for rice meals which you can't get at the noodle/soup place beside the hotel.  About the only downside was the TV reception, but then there really wasn't much time to watch TV anyway since I had to be up at like 5 45 am :).

Un chambre bon marchÃ© pour partir le lendemain direction Phnom Penh, mais rien d'autre. Les propriÃ©taires sont souriants et ont pu m'aider Ã  booker le trajet vers le Cambodge, malgrÃ© leur niveau d'anglais et la chambre Ã©tait propre avec un bon wifi, mais Ã  part Ã§a, c'est excentrÃ© et bruyant Ã  cause de divers karaokÃ©s dans le coin.

h_title_comment: Good for one night in a border town, but not any longer...
h_comment: Vy Khanh was a bit of a walk from the waterfront. Since we would only be here for one night before catching the boat to Phnom Penh the following day, I didn't want to spend much on a room. We paid $10. It was a fine room for one night, but definitely had a musty/smoky odor. The best part about this guest house was the excellent wifi.  Karaoke is big here and you could definitely hear some people singing into the night, but not a big deal.

h_title_comment: Good location but rip off bus prices
h_comment: We stayed here for two nights as we could not get a connecting bus to Ha Tien. The rooms were clean and decent bathrooms. There was a TV in the room but the plug was broken. The restaurant had some good choices at reasonable price, overall it was a pleasant stay. The location is great, with all amenities very close by.  However, when we asked for bus prices to Ha Tien, we were quoted $8 which is ridiculously expensive. We managed to get a ticket for $3, so I do not suggest booking anything using the tour desk here. The receptionist also appeared very annoyed that we did not book with her despite the ridiculous price.

Staff here were very friendly and helpful. We were part of a large group. They were very accommodating. The location is very central, one street away from the local markets, plus there is quite a few decent eating places within walking distance. For budget accommodation on your way to somewhere else it was very adequate.

We stayed one night during Mekong Delta -tour, but never again. Street-side-room was quite clean with  out-off-date furnitures and one sheet to lie on, poor bathroom. Breakfast-menu was normal, but omelet was not cooked well and  juice was finished. Breakfast service was slow. We can recommend in emergency for very short stay.

Petit hotel tres frequente notamment par les tours provenant de Saigon ou Phnom Penh. Pour les voyageurs independants il y a tout de meme quelques chambres a bas prix (7 USD la double). Cependant il n'y a pas de fenetres mais une sorte d'ouverture avec des barres en beton et sans moustiquaire. Pas de soucis pour ce qui est du froid mais par contre les moustiques !!! Petit restaurant en bas, pas tres bon rapport qualite prix et en plus il y a de nombreux pousse-pousse en bas qui passent la soiree a vous proposer d'aller faire un tour, ca va 5 mn mais au bout de 2h !!!

siamo arrivati in questo albergo con il tour del Mekong. Albergo situato nella zona del mercato. le stanze hanno due letti molto grandi ma la stanza era molto sporca. Il personale non parla inglese. La mattina al momento del check out l'addetta Ã¨ stata molto scortese per dieci minuti di ritardo al momento della richiesta dei passaporti li ha consegnati molto sgarbatamente. La wifi al terzo piano non funzionava almeno nella nostra stanza la 301. Colazione minima. Stanza economica. Struttura non consigliata.

h_title_comment: Not bad for a short stay
h_comment: Clean and spacious room with fan and AC. Beds were big and good.  The hot shower didn't work but it was so hot that we didn't mind the cold water.   Only one person from the staff speaks good English, but she's usually not there. With the rest it was rather difficult to communicate. They were friendly and helpful though.   Breakfast was not that good but there are not may options in the area so you might as well have it.   We stayed for two nights and can't really complain, though being it so cheap, you get what you pay for.

very clean room, very cheap. also the food is very good.  not far from the centre of chau doc.  very good staff willing toi help you, very well organised for doing trips.  would go back ther if ur travelling on budget.

h_title_comment: Well, it was cheap, I'll give it that
h_comment: With cheapness came filth, dusty airs and a non functionin air conditioning, but then you can't expect a lot from such a place. In true Vietnamese tradition, the folks outside honked their car horns a lot and the window's didn't have any sound isolation, which wasn't good for sleep. The staff wasn't very helpful and seemed even rude at times. We reserved this hotel through the same company that we bought a Mekong Delta cruise from and not knowing anything about it, we caved into the cyclo sellers at the harbour who then scooted us the massive 200 metre distance to the hotel :D  Vinh Phuoc's "restaurant" food (more like a lobby kiosk) wasn't anything to write home about either. Many of the dishes on their menu weren't actually available and what we did get was very simple

Es gibt Zimmer nur mit Ventilator und solche mit AC zusÃ¤tzlich (die Fernbedienung fÃ¼r die Klimaanlage bekommt man beim Einchecken), die Air Condition in unserem Zimmer allerdings ziemlich altersschwach, Ventilator war die ganze Nacht erforderlich. Part of a Mekong Delta/ Cambodia trip. Stayed in many Vietnam hotels but this was one of the worst- but what do you expect on a low budget package tour?

room single at 6$, bargained 5$: clean, double bed, tv, water as extra, towels, toothbrush, toilet paper, soap, attached bathroom / western toilet / hot shower, bucket, free wifi but only at reception/restaurant (still, other networks visible on 3F), small "window", tours/bus/map of city available.  The bus/boat trip from Phnom Penh by Mekong tour arrives here and after a quick tour of a few hotels, it is right in budget range.

h_title_comment: Just plain blah - had to stay there because of tour
h_comment: Another hotel I had to stay as part of Mekong delta tour.  Thankfully this one has balcony so we managed to have plenty supply of air in in such a hot climate in this area.  No frills but seriously if you are on budget and fancy nothing, this is decent enough. Don't know about the value-for-money though. Like I said, stayed there because its arranged by tour.

Stayed here one night on my way to Cambodia. unfriendly staff, rooms not clean...overall not a nice stay, if you can avoid it..although it could be difficult especially if you have bought a 3 days trip on the Mekong...it's part of the deal.

Die Ãœbernachtung im Hotel wurde von dem Reiseveranstalter einer 3-Tagestour zum Mekongdelta organisiert. Ich hatte ein Zimmer mit Fenster, das man nicht richtig schlieÃŸen konnte. h_title_comment: dont stay there,only if you dont have an alternative!
h_comment: really dont stay there, for 10 usd/ night you should find something else!!   rooms are very poor, the windows doesnt close very good and you get a lot of noise all night long!   at 4 am they open the local pub next to the hotel and you ll listen a lot of vietmamese people talking.... at 4(four) in the morning!!!   really it was terrible!

h_title_comment: Don't stay here if you don't have to
h_comment: We didn't pick this hotel ourselves as it was included as part of a travel package.  I assume we had the cheapest rooms but even so it was a real disapointment.   The room was small, very very dated with nasty polyester sheets on the beds.   The fan barely worked and as the windows did not open the heat became unbearable over the course of the night.   The staff really couldn't be bothered to help. They spent all their time on the Internet hardly able to look away from it when curtly answering questions  After breakfast I used the bathroom in reception. This was accessed through a pretty ditrty looking kitchen.    I didn't enjoy my stay here one bit.

DO NOT STAY HERE! We stayed here as part of a tour from Cambodia to Vietnam. We did not choose the hotel and like everyone else on the trip got put into this dirty excuse for a hotel. There were flies and bugs everywhere like a plague. The rooms barely fit a bed in, the bed was dirty and the matress had springs comming out of the middle. The walls, floor and bathroom were black with dirt. The windows were two slits in the wall with no netting to stop things comming in. We ate here and the chicken came raw, and the pork with rice had an elastic band in the middle. We complained along with almost every other guest and the staff basically said tough. Book your own accommodation if doing the border crossing, even if it means paying more, at least you won't wake up with food

We booked tickets from Phnom penh to Phu Quoc Island with one overnight in Chau Doc. The Vinh Phuoc hotel was included. We found it a quite depressive place to stay. The entrance was very dirty, you had to clime a lot of stairs with your luggage to enter the depressive room with a lot of street noise, sheets with burning marks,  The bathroom was the only place that was allright.

h_title_comment: Tried to rob everyone who walked through the door
h_comment: Rude and ignorant staff , they tried to overcharge us for the boat to cambodia and got a right strop on when we questoined the price , also tried to overcharge us for dinner as did the two tables around us , we've been to Vietnam twice now and these jokers are  the worst  we've ever come across in a land of lovely people, a really helpful bookshop, money exchange , breakfast bar and ticket bookers is located next to the Song Sao hotel run by an older couple couldn't be reccomended highly enough.

h_title_comment: Clean budget accommodation in Chau Doc, Vietnam
h_comment: Another clean and tidy one star hotel on our 3 day Mekong Delta tour from Saigon. Not an ounce of luxury hotel, but it is cheap and cheerful with friendly staff.  Our twin room consisted of 2 x double and 1 x single bed, satellite tv that had no sound, chair, bedside table and wardrobe. Window in room looked out on a wall of another building and door to the small dark balcony was locked shut. Cooling was by way of a wall fan. Air conditioning is in the room and if wanted, an extra US$5 will get you the key to the power switch for it. A small bathroom with hand basin, toilet and shower that sprays into the room making the floor and toilet wet. Towels are provided, but take your own soap as we did, because it isnâ€™t supplied here.
